(Not sure if this is the right category)

Inspired by this post:

FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears? General Forum
Hey everyone, I’m getting excited to gear up for competition season (and thus my Chief Delphi intake has gone up), and I was curious, what pet peeves do you have in FRC? These could be about the program, misconceptions, things that people say “incorrectly”, or anything else you all think applies. I’ll go ahead first. I don’t like when people refer to the sparkMAX motor control as a spark. That’s a whole different product, that is aimed at a completely different set of motors! Now your turn, w…

What are your programming pet peeves? This could be about how your teamates write code, or something in wpilib or external vendor libraries /api’s that you that you might not like, or anything else.

Hungarian notation, especially since all the WPILib examples use it without explaining why. This means it could easily end up in lots of teams’ code where no one has any real idea why it’s there.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":206,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T21:18:06.109Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":1053,"readers_count":1052,"score":475.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492214,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":17}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves/492214/6","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":17}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":17,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531930,"name":"Stephen Ostermiller","username":"stephen.ostermiller","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stephen.ostermiller/{size}/188076_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T21:19:04.115Z","cooked":"

When people post to these forums asking for help with their code and all you have to work with is a screenshot of their code. If I want to help them and correct their code, I need to type it all out again. Some important bits will probably be cut off.

Those asking for help are likely students with little experience, so I try to cut them some slack. But there are two really good ways to share code:

  1. Use markdown formatting with code blocks using three backticks at the start and end. Specifying the language after the first three backticks:
    ```java
int x = 3;
int y = 4;
```
  2. Share a link to the file you are working on in your branch in your github repository.
","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":206,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T21:19:04.115Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":992,"readers_count":991,"score":533.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492214,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves","display_username":"Stephen Ostermiller","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-pet-peeves-what-really-grinds-your-gears/491352/488","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":22}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57904,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1073 mentor viperscout.com"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves/492214/7","custom_user_title":"1073 mentor viperscout.com","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":22}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531939,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T21:27:46.031Z","cooked":"

Open command pallete
WPILIB Simulate Robot Code
Wait for a rebuild/check
“Sim Gui or Real Driverstation”
then it launches the sim.

Every single time I run this I get distracted by something else during that few seconds (or minutes on some student laptops), click away from prompt and have to start over. If it’d just ask before doing the rest of the process it’d be fine.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":206,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T21:27:46.031Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":954,"readers_count":953,"score":650.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492214,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":30}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves/492214/8","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":28},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":30,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531959,"name":"","username":"SmartKirb99","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e495f1/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T21:51:15.458Z","cooked":"

The change in WPILib (This Year) that then required Spark Maxes (Unsure if that is the plural for Spark Max) to require an additional object, being a SparkMaxConfig, to invert motors, instead of just saying m_insertMotorHere.setInverted(); as I don’t think FIRST wants us using deprecated code.

Edit: Realized that it was due to RevLib and not WPILib

I think you have a bone to pick with Rev Robotics, not WPILib. Revlib is the library used to control Spark Maxes (I am going along with this pluralization), which is separate from WPILib.

Feedback and feedforward constants without units, espeically if they are not in base SI units and radians.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":206,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T22:12:07.072Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":860,"readers_count":859,"score":262.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492214,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-programming-pet-peeves/492214/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531998,"name":"Jason Daming","username":"jdaming","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jdaming/{size}/137720_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T22:13:21.889Z","cooked":"

Do you often find yourself choosing each of them? A little known option is to bypass this check by changing “Skip Select Simulate Extension” in the vscode optoins for WPILib.

For example I almost never do DS sim so just have it always auto go to the simGUI but some people have it auto skip simGUI etc.

Another recently discovered pet peeve I have: Trying to figure out commands and subsystems in C++, I have no clue why there is a file called Command.h and a file called Command.cpp for one command, I’m very much used to Java and therefore one file per command (or subsystem)

Why have header files and .cpp files?

c++, header-files
answered by paercebal on 01:47PM - 02 Dec 08 UTC

It can still be your pet peeve, but there are technical reasons based on how C++ is defined and implemented.
